This is your second practice exam for the Missouri Class F knowledge test. You need 20 correct answers out of 25 questions to pass (80%).

docs.title: Full Practice Test 2
docs.text:
#

What is the minimum age to obtain a full (unrestricted) Class F driver license in Missouri?

16 years old17 years old18 years old21 years old

You must be 18 years old to obtain a full, unrestricted Class F driver license in Missouri.

#

During the Intermediate License stage, drivers under 18 cannot drive between what hours?

10 PM and 5 AM11 PM and 6 AM1 AM and 5 AMMidnight and 4 AM

Intermediate license holders cannot drive between 1 AM and 5 AM unless for work, school, or emergencies.

#

What shape is a yield sign?

CircleOctagonTriangle pointing downDiamond

A yield sign is a downward-pointing triangle (inverted triangle).

#

An orange diamond-shaped sign indicates:

School zoneWork zoneRailroad crossingNo passing zone

Orange signs indicate construction or maintenance work zones.

#

What does a flashing yellow traffic signal mean?

Stop, then proceed when safeSlow down and proceed with cautionPrepare to stopYield to cross traffic

Flashing yellow means proceed with caution - slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.

#

A broken white line between lanes means:

No lane changes allowedLane changes permitted when safeExit lane onlyCarpool lane

Broken white lines separate lanes moving in the same direction and indicate lane changes are permitted when safe.

#

What does a steady yellow traffic light mean?

Speed up to get through the intersectionStop immediatelyPrepare to stop; the light is about to turn redProceed with caution

Yellow means the light is about to turn red - stop if you can do so safely.

#

At a four-way stop, if four vehicles arrive simultaneously, who goes first?

The largest vehicleThe vehicle that flashes its lightsDrivers should use courtesy and eye contact to determine who goes firstThe vehicle going straight

When all arrive at the same time, drivers should use courtesy, eye contact, and common sense to determine right-of-way.

#

What is the maximum speed limit on Missouri interstate highways (unless posted otherwise)?

55 mph65 mph70 mph75 mph

Missouri's maximum speed limit on rural interstates is 70 mph unless otherwise posted.

#

When changing lanes, you should:

Signal, check mirrors, turnCheck mirrors, signal, check blind spot, change lanes when safeSignal and change lanes immediatelyHonk your horn and change lanes

Proper sequence: check mirrors, signal, check blind spot, then change lanes when safe.

#

You should dim your headlights within ____ feet when following another vehicle:

100 feet200 feet300 feet500 feet

Dim your high beams within 300 feet when following another vehicle.

#

When parallel parking uphill with a curb, turn your wheels:

Away from the curbToward the curbStraightEither direction

When parking uphill WITH a curb, turn wheels away from the curb so the car rolls backward into the curb if brakes fail.

#

You must not park within ____ feet of a crosswalk:

10 feet15 feet20 feet25 feet

Do not park within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection.

#

When exiting a highway, you should:

Speed up on the exit rampSlow down in the right lane before the exitMove into the deceleration lane and then slow downStop before entering the exit ramp

Use the deceleration (exit) lane to slow down - don't slow in the through lane.

#

What does a white X over a highway lane mean?

Lane is endingHigh occupancy vehicle laneLane is closed - do not drive in this laneConstruction zone ahead

A white X means the lane is closed to traffic - you must not drive in that lane.

#

You must stop for a school bus when:

Its yellow lights are flashingIts red lights are flashing and stop arm is extendedIt is stopped at an intersectionAll of the above

You must stop when the red lights are flashing and the stop arm is extended.

#

A pedestrian using a white cane or guide dog:

Has the right-of-way in all situationsShould wait for traffic to clearIs blind or visually impaired and must be given right-of-wayIs requesting assistance

A white cane or guide dog indicates the person is blind or visually impaired and must always be given right-of-way.

#

When driving in rain, you should:

Increase speed to get through it quicklyUse cruise control to maintain steady speedReduce speed and increase following distanceTurn on hazard lights

Rain reduces traction and visibility - slow down and increase following distance.

#

Black ice is most likely to form:

In the middle of the dayOn bridges and overpassesIn sunny areasOn uphill slopes only

Bridges and overpasses freeze first because cold air circulates above and below them.

#

The legal blood alcohol concentration (BAC) limit for drivers 21 and over is:

0.02%0.05%0.08%0.10%

For drivers 21 and older, the legal BAC limit is 0.08%.

#

Using a cell phone while driving (for any purpose other than emergency):

Is legal for experienced driversIs legal with hands-free deviceTexting is illegal for all driversIs only illegal for drivers under 21

Texting while driving is illegal for all Missouri drivers. However, talking on a phone (hands-free or handheld) is currently legal for drivers 22 and over.

#

Accumulating 12 points in 12 months results in:

Warning letterLicense suspensionMandatory traffic schoolIncreased insurance rates only

12 points in 12 months (or 18 points in 24 months, or 8 points in 18 months) results in license suspension.

#

Running a red light results in how many points?

2 points3 points4 points6 points

Running a red light or stop sign is 2 points.

#

Child safety seats are required for children under what age?

4 years old6 years old8 years old10 years old

Missouri law requires appropriate child restraints for children under 8 years old (or under 80 pounds).

#

When should you check your blind spots?

Only when changing lanesBefore changing lanes and when mergingEvery 5 secondsOnly when backing up

Always check blind spots before changing lanes and when merging onto highways.

docs.title: Full Practice Test 3
docs.text:
#

How many hours of behind-the-wheel training are required for drivers under 18 to obtain a license?

20 hours30 hours40 hours50 hours

Missouri requires 40 hours of behind-the-wheel training (including 10 hours at night) for drivers under 18.

#

With an Instruction Permit, you may drive when accompanied by:

Any licensed driverA licensed driver 21 or older in the front seatYour instructor onlyAnyone with a permit

Instruction Permit holders must have a licensed driver 21 or older seated in the front passenger seat.

#

A red octagonal sign means:

YieldStopDo not enterWrong way

An octagon (8-sided) red sign is always a STOP sign.

#

A diamond-shaped yellow sign with a black 'X' and 'RR' indicates:

Construction zoneRailroad crossing aheadIntersection aheadSchool zone

The yellow diamond with X and RR warns of a railroad crossing ahead.

#

A green traffic light means:

Go without lookingSpeed upProceed when it is safe to do soYou have the absolute right-of-way

Green means go when it is safe - you must still yield to pedestrians and vehicles already in the intersection.

#

A solid yellow line on your side of the center line means:

Passing is permittedPassing is not permittedNo parkingLane ends ahead

A solid yellow line on your side means you cannot pass. Passing is only allowed when you have a broken line on your side.

#

What does a red arrow on a traffic signal mean?

Yield before turning in the direction of the arrowYou may turn after stoppingYou cannot turn in the direction of the arrowProceed with caution in the direction of the arrow

A red arrow means you must NOT turn in that direction - wait for a green signal.

#

If two vehicles arrive at an intersection with stop signs at the same time, who has the right-of-way?

The larger vehicleThe vehicle on the leftThe vehicle on the rightThe vehicle going straight

When two vehicles arrive simultaneously, the vehicle on the RIGHT has the right-of-way.

#

What is Missouri's 'Move Over Law'?

Change lanes for any slow vehicleMove over or slow down for stopped emergency vehicles with flashing lightsPull over for all emergency vehiclesChange lanes at intersections

Missouri's Move Over Law requires drivers to move over a lane (or slow down if unable to move over) for stopped emergency vehicles with flashing lights.

#

You should signal at least ____ feet before turning in urban areas:

50 feet75 feet100 feet150 feet

Signal at least 100 feet before turning in urban areas (city/town).

#

When should you use high beam headlights?

Always at nightIn city trafficOn open highways when there is no oncoming trafficIn fog

Use high beams on open highways when there is no oncoming or nearby traffic. Dim them within 500 feet of oncoming traffic and 300 feet when following.

#

When parallel parking downhill, you should turn your wheels:

Away from the curbToward the curbStraight aheadIt doesn't matter

When parking downhill, turn wheels toward the curb so the car will roll into the curb if brakes fail.

#

You must not park within ____ feet of a fire hydrant:

5 feet10 feet15 feet20 feet

Never park within 10 feet of a fire hydrant.

#

When entering a highway from an entrance ramp, you should:

Stop and wait for an openingForce your way into trafficMatch the speed of highway traffic and merge when safeEnter slowly and speed up after merging

Use the acceleration lane to match highway speed, then merge smoothly when there's a safe gap.

#

On a multi-lane highway, which lane should slower traffic use?

Left laneMiddle laneRight laneAny lane

Slower traffic should keep right. Use left lanes for passing.

#

When a school bus is stopped with flashing red lights on a two-lane road, drivers must:

Stop only if traveling in the same directionStop in both directionsSlow down and proceed with cautionChange lanes

On a two-lane road, traffic in BOTH directions must stop for a school bus with flashing red lights.

#

When sharing the road with motorcycles, you should:

Assume they will move out of your wayGive them less space since they're smallerGive them a full lane widthDrive close to encourage them to speed up

Motorcycles are entitled to a full lane width - don't share the lane with them.

#

Hydroplaning occurs when:

Your tires are newYou drive too slow in rainWater builds up between your tires and the road surfaceYour windshield wipers fail

Hydroplaning happens when water builds up faster than your tires can push it away, causing you to lose traction.

#

When driving in fog, you should:

Use high beam headlightsUse low beam headlights and fog lights if equippedTurn off all lightsUse hazard lights

Use low beams in fog - high beams reflect back and reduce visibility. Use fog lights if your vehicle has them.

#

For drivers under 21, Missouri has a Zero Tolerance law with a BAC limit of:

0.00%0.02%0.05%0.08%

Missouri has Zero Tolerance for drivers under 21 - any measurable BAC (0.02% or higher) results in penalties.

#

Implied consent means:

You consent to obey traffic lawsBy operating a vehicle, you consent to chemical testing if arrested for DWIYou consent to allow police to search your vehicleYou consent to vehicle insurance requirements

Missouri's Implied Consent law means by driving, you automatically consent to chemical testing (breath, blood, urine) if arrested for DWI.

#

How many points does speeding result in?

2 points3 points4 pointsIt depends on how fast over the limit

Speeding violations are 3 points in Missouri.

#

If you accumulate 8 points in 18 months, what happens?

NothingWarning letter30-day license suspension1-year license revocation

8 points in 18 months results in a 30-day license suspension.

#

Your vehicle's horn should be used:

To alert other drivers of dangerTo express angerTo greet friendsWhenever you want

Use your horn only to alert others of danger or to avoid a collision.

#

Tire tread depth should be at least:

1/16 inch1/8 inch2/32 inch1/4 inch

Missouri law requires at least 2/32 inch of tire tread depth (use the penny test - Lincoln's head should be partially covered).

docs.text:
#

At what age can you apply for an Instruction Permit in Missouri?

14 years old15 years old16 years old17 years old

Missouri allows teens to apply for an instruction permit at age 15.

#

How many hours of behind-the-wheel driving practice are required during the Intermediate License stage?

20 hours30 hours40 hours50 hours

The GDL program requires 40 hours of supervised driving practice, including 10 hours at night.

#

What documents are required to obtain a driver's license in Missouri?

Birth certificate onlySocial Security card onlyProof of identity, Social Security number, and Missouri residencySchool ID and utility bill

All three types of documents are required: proof of identity, Social Security number, and Missouri residency.

#

What does a red octagon sign mean?

YieldStopDo Not EnterWrong Way

The octagon (8-sided) shape is unique to stop signs.

#

A flashing red traffic signal should be treated as:

A stop signA yield signCaution, proceed carefullyThe signal is broken, ignore it

Come to a complete stop, yield to traffic, then proceed when safe - just like a stop sign.

#

What does a solid yellow center line on your side mean?

Passing is permitted in either directionNo passing allowed on your sideTwo-way traffic aheadRight turn only

A solid yellow line on your side means do not pass.

#

At a green arrow traffic signal, you should:

Stop and waitProceed with caution after yieldingProceed in the direction of the arrow; oncoming traffic is stoppedTreat it like a yield sign

Green arrow means protected movement - oncoming traffic is held by a red signal.

#

When two vehicles arrive at an uncontrolled intersection at the same time, who has the right-of-way?

The vehicle on the leftThe vehicle on the rightThe larger vehicleThe faster vehicle

When in doubt, yield to the right.

#

What is the speed limit in a school zone when children are present?

15 mph20 mph25 mph30 mph

School zones are 20 mph when children are present or signs indicate school is in session.

#

When following another vehicle, you should maintain a following distance of at least:

1 second2 seconds3 seconds5 seconds

Use the 3-second rule under normal conditions. Increase in bad weather or heavy traffic.

#

You must use your headlights:

From sunset to sunrise onlyWhenever you use your windshield wipersWhen visibility is less than 500 feetAll of the above

Headlights are required from sunset to sunrise, when using wipers, and when visibility is reduced.

#

When parking on a hill without a curb, you should turn your wheels:

Straight aheadToward the shoulder of the roadAway from the shoulderIt doesn't matter

This allows the vehicle to roll away from traffic if brakes fail.

#

You cannot park within how many feet of a fire hydrant?

5 feet10 feet15 feet20 feet

Must maintain at least 15 feet from a fire hydrant.

#

When entering a highway from an entrance ramp, you should:

Stop and wait for an openingEnter at or near the speed of trafficEnter slowly and speed up graduallySound your horn to alert other drivers

Match the flow of traffic for a safe merge.

#

If you miss your exit on a highway, you should:

Stop and back upMake a U-turn when safeContinue to the next exitDrive across the median

Never stop, back up, or make dangerous maneuvers on a highway.

#

When a school bus has its red lights flashing and stop arm extended, you must:

Slow down and proceed with cautionStop at least 10 feet awayStop only if you're behind the busChange lanes to pass

Stop for a school bus with flashing red lights, both directions (unless divided highway).

#

When sharing the road with large trucks, you should avoid:

Their blind spots (No-Zones)Following too closelyCutting in front of themAll of the above

Large trucks have large blind spots, need more stopping distance, and require extra space.

#

When driving in fog, you should:

Use high beam headlightsUse low beam headlightsTurn off your headlightsUse parking lights only

High beams reflect off fog and reduce visibility. Use low beams.

#

If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, you should:

Brake firmlyAccelerate to get through the waterEase off the gas and steer straightTurn sharply to one side

Let the vehicle slow naturally and maintain control.

#

Missouri law prohibits drivers under 21 from:

Using a handheld phone while drivingDriving with any detectable amount of alcoholDriving between midnight and 5 AMHaving more than one passenger

Zero tolerance law - drivers under 21 cannot have any detectable amount of alcohol.

#

Sending or reading a text message while driving is:

Legal if under 21 years oldIllegal for all drivers in MissouriLegal if at a red lightOnly illegal for commercial drivers

Texting while driving is prohibited for all drivers in Missouri.

#

How many points will result in a license suspension for a driver under 18?

6 points in 12 months8 points in 18 months10 points in 24 months12 points in 12 months

Drivers under 18 face suspension at 8 points in 18 months.

#

Speeding 20 mph over the limit results in how many points?

2 points3 points4 points6 points

Excessive speeding (20+ mph over limit) is 4 points.

#

Safety belts must be worn by:

Driver onlyFront seat passengers onlyAll occupants of the vehicleOnly passengers under 18

Missouri law requires all occupants to wear seat belts.

#

Your vehicle must be inspected every:

6 months1 year2 years3 years

Missouri requires safety inspections every two years (or annually for certain vehicles).

docs.title: What this chapter covers
docs.text: Overview of Missouri Class F (non-commercial) driver licensing: who is eligible, how Graduated Driver Licensing (GDL) works, which documents you need, and your responsibilities to keep your license valid.

docs.title: Learning objectives
docs.text:
• Differentiate permit, intermediate, and full license stages (GDL) and their purposes.
  • Identify required proofs (identity/legal presence, Social Security number, Missouri residency).
  • Describe the vision, knowledge, and road testing sequence at a high level.
  • Explain renewal basics and when you must report name or address changes.

Verify official specifics

Numeric details (ages, timeframes, passenger limits, time-of-night restrictions, renewal periods, and distances) can change. Always verify the latest Missouri Driver Guide for exact values.

docs.title: 1. Class F overview
docs.text:
Class F is Missouri’s standard non-commercial license for operating typical passenger cars and light trucks. It does not authorize commercial driving (CDL) or motorcycle operation unless properly endorsed.

Key ideas:

  • It’s a privilege granted by the state, conditioned on knowledge, skill, and safe conduct.
  • Operation requires current, valid licensing; driving on an expired, suspended, or revoked license can lead to points and further sanctions.

docs.title: 2. Graduated Driver Licensing (GDL)
docs.text:
GDL phases let new drivers gain experience in lower-risk steps before full privileges. Missouri's structure (verify specifics in the official guide) generally includes:

  1. Instruction permit
    • Supervised driving only with a qualified, properly licensed adult in the front seat.
    • May include passenger and nighttime limits intended to reduce exposure to high‑risk conditions.
  2. Intermediate license
    • Allows unsupervised driving with specific limitations (for example, nighttime driving windows and passenger count rules for younger drivers—verify details).
    • Clean driving history for a minimum period is typically required to progress.
  3. Full license
    • Graduated restrictions lift once age, time, and incident‑free criteria are met.

Why this matters:

  • Crash risk is highest early in licensure; restrictions target the riskiest conditions (night driving, multiple teen passengers) to improve outcomes.

docs.title: 3. Documents and identification
docs.text:
Expect to provide original or certified documentation in the following categories:

  • Identity and lawful presence (e.g., birth certificate or passport; verify accepted forms).
  • Social Security number (card or acceptable proof).
  • Missouri residency (usually two documents such as utility bill, bank statement, or lease).

Tips to avoid delays:

  • Names must match across documents; fix mismatches with the issuing agency first.
  • Bring recent, legible documents. Electronic proofs may be allowed in some cases—verify.

docs.title: REAL ID note
docs.text: Missouri issues both REAL ID‑compliant and non‑REAL ID credentials. Review the state’s REAL ID guidance to decide which you need for federal facility/air travel purposes.

docs.title: 4. Testing sequence (high level)
docs.text:
You'll typically complete:

  1. Vision screening
    • Confirms minimum acuity and peripheral awareness for safe driving.
  2. Knowledge exam
    • Multiple‑choice rules-of-the-road, signage, and safe driving practices.
  3. Road test
    • Demonstrates basic control, observation, signaling, and compliance with law.

Note: Chapter 2 ("Exam Process") covers test logistics and readiness in greater detail.

docs.title: Visual overview
docs.text: The typical order is Vision → Knowledge → Road test.

docs.title: 5. Validity, renewal, and changes
docs.text:
• Renewal periods can vary by age category. Check your credential’s expiration date and renew ahead of time.
  • You must update the state after a legal name change or change of address within the required timeframe.
  • Keep your license accessible while driving; some interactions, like traffic stops or crashes, require you to present it.

Consequences of lapses:

  • Driving after expiration or during a suspension/revocation can lead to citations, points, and insurance/record impacts.

docs.title: 6. Responsibilities and safe conduct
docs.text:
Licensing signals minimum competence, not perfection. Ongoing responsibilities include:

  • Drive sober and alert; never drive impaired by alcohol, drugs, or fatigue.
  • Maintain financial responsibility (insurance) and legal registration of your vehicle.
  • Model courteous, predictable behavior—signal early, yield appropriately, and manage space.

docs.title: 7. Common pitfalls and how to avoid them
docs.text:
• Incomplete documentation → Use a printed checklist and verify acceptable forms on the state site.
  • Name/address mismatches → Resolve with SSA and issuing agencies before your visit.
  • Overlooking GDL limits → Post a reminder card in the vehicle; set phone alerts for time windows.
  • Studying passively → Use active recall (cover the page, list key points, check, repeat).

docs.title: 3 things to remember
docs.text:
• GDL stages build experience safely before full privileges; know each stage’s limits.
  • Bring identity, SSN, and Missouri residency proofs that match across documents.
  • The sequence is vision → knowledge → road; prepare actively, not passively.

docs.title: Exam Process (Chapter 2)
docs.text:
TL;DR

Expect vision, knowledge, and a road test. Prep with active recall, mock drives, and a working vehicle + documents so exam day is smooth.

docs.title: What this chapter covers
docs.text: The sequence, expectations, and preparation strategies for the vision screening, knowledge exam, and road test required to obtain (or advance) a Missouri Class F license. Numeric specifics (ages, waiting periods, number of questions, passing scores) must be verified in the current Missouri Driver Guide.

docs.title: Learning objectives
docs.text:
• Outline the order of typical exam components.
  • Identify readiness indicators for scheduling your road test.
  • Apply study and practice methods that reduce first‑time failure risk.
  • Recognize common failure causes and remediation strategies.

docs.title: 1. Overview of examination flow
docs.text:
Typical order (verify official flow):

  1. Document + identity verification
  2. Vision screening
  3. Knowledge (written) exam
  4. Instruction permit phase (practice driving under supervision)
  5. Road test (skill/driving test)

Progression requires passing earlier steps and meeting any time, age, or supervised hour requirements.

docs.title: Visual overview
docs.text:
Plan prep for each phase in the sequence.

Purpose: Ensure minimum visual acuity and peripheral vision to drive safely.

You should:

  • Address correctable vision issues (e.g., updated prescription lenses) before testing.
  • Know whether you must wear corrective lenses; license may include a restriction code if required.

Failure pathway: If you do not meet standards, you may need an eye professional’s statement or to improve with corrective measures before proceeding.

docs.title: 3. Knowledge exam
docs.text:
Scope (paraphrased categories):

  • Signs, signals, and pavement markings.
  • Right‑of‑way rules, lane usage, and speed management.
  • Parking regulations and special condition driving (weather, nighttime, work zones).
  • Effects of impairment (alcohol, drugs), distractions, and safety practices.
  • Point system basics (consequences of violations).

Effective study pattern:

  1. Active reading: Summarize each section into bullet points.
  2. Spaced recall: Quiz yourself daily using self‑generated questions.
  3. Mixed practice: Interleave topics (signs, right‑of‑way, parking) to build flexible recall.
  4. Error log: Track missed practice questions; revisit underlying guide paragraphs.

Common mistakes:

  • Pure passive reading without recall.
  • Cramming only night before exam.
  • Ignoring signage nuances (shape/color coding).

docs.title: 4. Road test readiness
docs.text:
Indicators you might be ready (verify official supervised hour requirements):

  • You can execute smooth starts, stops, lane changes, and turns without prompts.
  • You consistently check mirrors and blind spots (head movement) before lane changes & merges.
  • You maintain safe following distance and speed adaptation.
  • You scan ahead for hazards (pedestrians, signals, brake lights).
  • You self‑correct minor errors immediately.

Pre‑test checklist:

  • Vehicle: Lights, signals, horn, mirrors, tires all functional; valid registration & insurance.
  • Documents: Permit/license, required ID, any completion forms.
  • Practice: Several recent drives in varied conditions (day/night, urban/suburban) if allowed.

docs.title: 5. Road test structure
docs.text:
Typical evaluated elements:

  • Vehicle control: Steering, acceleration, braking smoothness.
  • Observation: Mirror checks, shoulder checks, hazard scanning.
  • Positioning: Lane centering, proper entry/exit from turns, correct lane choices.
  • Compliance: Speed limits, signals, right‑of‑way rules, stop line adherence.
  • Communication: Timely signaling, appropriate horn use (rarely needed).

Immediate disqualifiers (examples—verify specifics):

  • Running a red light or failing to stop at a stop sign.
  • Dangerous maneuvers (near collision, severe speeding, reckless lane change).
  • Ignoring examiner instructions repeatedly.

docs.title: 6. Managing test anxiety
docs.text:
Approaches:

  • Structured breathing: Slow exhale before key maneuvers.
  • Verbalizing steps during practice ("Mirror, signal, shoulder check, move").
  • Mock exams with a supervising adult acting as examiner.
  • Sleep and nutrition: Avoid fatigue and low blood sugar.

Reframing: Treat the test as a demonstration of consistent habits—not perfection.

docs.title: 7. Failure analysis & retest strategy
docs.text:
If unsuccessful:

  • Write a brief post‑test reflection: list concrete errors.
  • Categorize: Observation, control, rules, positioning, anxiety.
  • Target: Design short drills for each category (e.g., mirror + shoulder check repetition in empty lot).
  • Schedule retest only after demonstrable improvement, not arbitrary waiting.

Knowledge retest: Focus on missed question types; craft 1–2 new questions from the guide paragraphs you misunderstood.

docs.title: 8. Ethical & safety focus
docs.text:
Passing demonstrates minimum competence. Ongoing responsibility:

  • Continue practicing advanced defensive driving (space & time margins).
  • Resist complacency: Revisit guide highlights periodically.
  • Model safe behavior for peers (especially during early unsupervised driving).

  • After misses, analyze errors by category and drill before retesting.

docs.title: Signs, Signals & Markings (Chapter 3)
docs.text:
TL;DR

Read shape + color first to infer intent, then confirm with text/symbol. Pavement lines govern where you may travel or pass—solid means hold, broken allows change when safe.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: Shapes, colors, and pavement markings that communicate regulatory, warning, and guidance information. Verify color or marking specifics (e.g., lane line meanings) in official guide.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
• Interpret sign shape & color at a glance.
  • Distinguish regulatory vs warning vs guide signage.
  • Apply pavement marking meanings to lane positioning & passing.
  • Recognize signal indications & lane control arrows.

docs.title: Left-Turn Signal Types Evolution
docs.text:
Modern flashing yellow arrow (FYA) heads replace traditional "doghouse" clusters. They give a clearer distinction between protected (green arrow) and permissive (flashing yellow arrow) phases and reduce driver confusion with circular greens.

Type Icon Phases Provided Notes Traditional Doghouse 5-Section • Red (stop)• Green circle + Green arrow (protected left)• Yellow circle + Yellow arrow (clearance)• Green circle (permissive left, yield to oncoming)• Yellow circle (clearance) Left turn only; typically has sign "Green Ball Yield to Oncoming Traffic" Vertical 5-Head Protected/Permissive • Red (stop)• Red + Green arrow (protected left)• Red + Yellow arrow (clearance)• Green circle (permissive left + through)• Yellow circle (clearance) Saves lateral space; still uses circular permissive green 4-Section FYA Arrow Head • Red arrow (stop)• Green arrow (protected left)• Steady yellow arrow (clearance)• Flashing yellow arrow (permissive left) Distinct flashing arrow conveys yield to opposing traffic 3-Section FYA Arrow Head • Red arrow (stop)• Green arrow (protected left)• Flashing yellow arrow (permissive left) Combines clearance into transition flash timing; used where simpler sequencing sufficient Protected-Only 3-Head • Red arrow (stop)• Green arrow (protected left)• Yellow arrow (clearance) All arrows; never yield on flashing yellow because none provided

Phase logic summary:

  • Green Arrow: Protected turn; opposing and pedestrian conflicts held.
  • Flashing Yellow Arrow: Permissive turn; yield to opposing traffic & pedestrians, then complete turn when gap exists.
  • Steady Yellow Arrow: Prepare to stop; protected phase ending.
  • Red Arrow: Stop—no turn allowed.

docs.title: Rules of the Road (Chapter 4)
docs.text:
TL;DR

Right-of-way is given, not taken; keep time-based following gaps and adapt speed to conditions (basic speed law) even if below the posted limit.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: Right-of-way, lane discipline, following distance, speed law application, and courtesy yielding. Verify any numeric thresholds in official guide.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
• Apply right-of-way at intersections and merges.
  • Maintain adequate time-based following distance.
  • Differentiate posted, advisory, and basic speed law responsibilities.
  • Execute safe lane changes and merges.

docs.title: 1. Right-of-Way Principles
docs.text:
Given—not taken. Priority examples:

  • First arrival at all-way stop proceeds first; simultaneous arrival: yield to right.
  • Left turns yield to oncoming straight/right-turning traffic.
  • Entering roadway (driveway/alley) yields to existing traffic.
  • Pedestrians in crosswalk (marked/unmarked) typically have priority.

docs.title: 4-way stop visual
docs.text: Yielding to the right avoids deadlocks at simultaneous arrival.

docs.title: 2. Lane Discipline
docs.text:
• Center your vehicle; avoid weaving.
  • Pass only where permitted & safe; allow clear sight distance.
  • Signal early; check mirrors then shoulder before lateral movement.
  • Avoid lingering in blind spots of larger vehicles.

docs.title: 3. Following Distance
docs.text:
Use second-count method; expand gap for:

  • Bad weather / low visibility.
  • Higher speeds (highway).
  • Following large obstructive vehicles.

docs.title: 4. Speed Management
docs.text:
• Posted limit: Maximum under ideal conditions.
  • Basic law: Adjust speed to conditions (may be well below posted).
  • Advisory signs: Suggest safe speed for specific hazard (curve, ramp) not enforceable as absolute limit.

docs.title: 5. Lane Change & Merge Sequence
docs.text: Mirror → signal → shoulder check → adjust speed/gap → move smoothly → cancel signal.

docs.title: 6. Courtesy & Defensive Yielding
docs.text:
• Allow merging vehicles space rather than forcing late braking.
  • Communicate intent clearly with consistent positioning & signaling.
  • Yield if another driver’s behavior suggests uncertainty.

docs.text:
• Lane change sequence: mirror → signal → shoulder check → adjust → move → cancel.
  • Expand following distance with speed and lower traction.
  • Basic speed law: slow to what’s safe for conditions, not just the posted limit.

docs.title: Parking (Chapter 5)
docs.text:
TL;DR

Know prohibited zones and how to set wheels on hills; practice a clear parallel parking sequence.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: Safe parking practices, prohibited locations, hill parking procedures, and visibility considerations. Verify distances (e.g., from fire hydrants, crosswalks) in official guide.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
• Identify common prohibited parking zones.
  • Apply uphill/downhill parking wheel positioning.
  • Execute parallel parking steps.
  • Enhance vehicle visibility & safety when parked.

docs.title: 1. Prohibited Locations (Examples)
docs.text:
Do not park:

  • In front of driveways.
  • Within specified feet of fire hydrants, crosswalks, stop signs (verify numbers).
  • On sidewalks or blocking pedestrian access.
  • In travel lanes or double-parked.
  • In designated accessible spaces without permit.

docs.title: 2. Hill Parking
docs.text:
Wheel direction changes prevent roll into traffic.
  • Uphill with curb: Turn wheels away from curb; vehicle rolls slightly back into curb.
  • Downhill with curb: Turn wheels toward curb; prevents forward roll.
  • No curb: Turn wheels toward road edge to avoid rolling into traffic.

Set parking brake; do not rely solely on transmission.

docs.title: 3. Parallel Parking Sequence
docs.text:
1. Signal + position beside forward vehicle (~parallel, short gap).
  2. Reverse turning toward curb, clearing rear bumper.
  3. Straighten wheels, continue backing.
  4. Turn opposite direction to center in space.
  5. Final adjustments leaving safe distance from vehicles ahead/behind.

docs.title: 4. Visibility & Security
docs.text:
• Use lights in poor visibility conditions when legally required (e.g., hazard lights if disabled).
  • Remove valuables from view; lock doors.
  • Avoid parking in blind curves or low-visibility crests.

docs.title: Quick Self-Check
docs.text:

docs.title: 3 things to remember
docs.text:
• Uphill with curb: wheels away; downhill: wheels toward curb; no curb: toward road edge.
  • Common no-parking areas: hydrants, crosswalks, driveways (verify distances).
  • Parallel parking: signal → reverse with angle → straighten → center → adjust.

docs.title: Highway Driving (Chapter 6)
docs.text:
TL;DR

Match traffic speed on entry, pass decisively, and expand time gaps—higher speeds magnify stopping distance and hazard exposure.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: Higher-speed driving strategies: merging, lane discipline, passing, speed & space management, hazard anticipation. Verify numeric speed advisories and any state-specific lane usage rules.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
• Execute safe merges and exits with proper speed matching.
  • Maintain lane discipline and appropriate passing etiquette.
  • Adjust following distance for higher speeds.
  • Anticipate hazards earlier via extended scanning.

docs.title: 1. Merging & Entry
docs.text:
• Accelerate in ramp lane to match main traffic speed (when safe).
  • Signal early; check mirrors & shoulder.
  • Select an appropriate gap—avoid forcing merges or stopping at ramp end unless necessary.

docs.title: 2. Lane Discipline
docs.text:
• Keep right except when passing (verify local rule enforcement).
  • Avoid frequent lane changes; they increase conflict points.
  • Use center and right lanes for steady travel; left lane primarily for passing.

docs.title: 3. Passing Strategy
docs.text:
• Signal, check blind spots, pass promptly without exceeding safe speed.
  • Re-enter lane only when you see the vehicle's front in your mirror.
  • Avoid passing in limited visibility or near ramps/exits.

docs.title: 4. Speed & Space Management
docs.text:
• Increase time gap as speed rises; higher speed = longer stopping distance.
  • Maintain a cushion ahead and to sides for escape routes.
  • Adjust speed smoothly; avoid abrupt braking in dense traffic.

docs.title: 5. Extended Scanning
docs.text:
Lane change steps reinforce deliberate, predictable movement.
  • Look farther ahead than city driving (multiple seconds of travel distance).
  • Identify slowdowns early (brake lights, congestion patterns).
  • Monitor entry ramps for merging conflicts.

docs.title: Quick Self-Check
docs.text:
• Why match speed when merging?
  • When is a pass complete safely?
  • Why expand following gap at highway speeds?

Proceed to quiz.

docs.title: 3 things to remember
docs.text:
• Merge by matching speed and selecting a clear gap; avoid stopping at ramp ends.
  • Finish a pass when you see the passed vehicle’s front in your mirror before returning.
  • Increase following distance as speed rises; smooth inputs prevent chain reactions.

docs.title: Quick Review
docs.text: How do you merge safely? Match traffic speed, signal, check mirrors and shoulder, and choose a clear gap.  When is it safe to move back after passing? When you can see the passed vehicle's front in your mirror.  Why increase following gap at higher speeds? Stopping distance and exposure increase with speed.

docs.title: Sharing the Road (Chapter 7)
docs.text:
TL;DR

Give extra space to vulnerable users, obey bus stop-arm rules, and avoid truck blind spots and wide-turn paths.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: Interaction with pedestrians, bicycles, motorcycles, school buses, large trucks, emergency & utility vehicles. Verify passing clearance distances and bus signal rules.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
• Identify vulnerability factors for various users.
  • Apply safe passing clearance.
  • Understand school bus light/stop arm protocol.
  • Adjust for large vehicle blind spots and turning radius.

docs.title: 1. Pedestrians
docs.text: Yield at crosswalks (marked/unmarked) when pedestrians present/entering. Reduce speed in dense foot traffic.

docs.title: 2. Bicycles
docs.text:
• Provide safe lateral clearance (verify distance).
  • Watch for lane position changes & hand signals.
  • Avoid squeezing between bicycle and parked cars (door zone).

docs.title: 3. Motorcycles
docs.text: Increase following distance; small profile may mask speed/distance judgment. Don’t assume persistent turn signal indicates imminent turn.

docs.title: 4. School Buses
docs.text: Red flashing lights + stop arm: Stop (unless divided highway exceptions apply). Yellow flashing: Prepare to stop. Extra caution for loading zones.

docs.title: 5. Large Trucks & Buses
docs.text: Wider turns, longer stopping distance, large blind spots. Avoid lingering in “No Zones.” Pass decisively, not slowly.

docs.title: Truck No‑Zones (blind spots)
docs.text: Stay out of no‑zones; pass decisively and don’t linger alongside.

docs.title: 6. Emergency / Utility Vehicles
docs.text: Move right & stop for approaching emergency vehicles. Slow/change lanes for stopped emergency/maintenance vehicles (Move Over law).

docs.title: Quick Self-Check
docs.text:
• Why more following distance behind trucks?
  • Difference between yellow and red bus lights?
  • How to avoid truck blind spots?

Proceed to quiz.

docs.title: 3 things to remember
docs.text:
• School bus: red lights + stop arm = stop (with limited divided-highway exceptions).
  • Large trucks have big “No Zones”; pass decisively and don’t linger alongside.
  • Provide safe lateral clearance when passing bicycles (verify distance).

docs.title: Quick Review
docs.text: Red flashing lights and stop arm on a school bus mean? Stop (with limited divided highway exceptions).  Why give trucks extra space? They have longer stopping distances and large blind spots.  Bicycle passing rule of thumb? Provide safe lateral clearance and avoid the door zone (verify exact distance).

docs.title: Everyday Driving Tips (Chapter 8)
docs.text:
TL;DR

Scan widely, signal early, keep space cushions, and drive predictably to reduce surprises for everyone.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: Routine safety habits: scanning, signaling, space cushions, courtesy interaction, hazard anticipation.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
• Build consistent mirror & shoulder check habits.
  • Maintain space cushions around vehicle.
  • Apply proactive hazard anticipation.
  • Practice courtesy to reduce unpredictable maneuvers.

docs.title: 1. Scanning & Observation
docs.text: Systematic glance pattern: front, mirrors, instrument cluster, blind spots when needed. Look several seconds ahead; identify potential conflicts early.

docs.title: Scan cycle visual
docs.text: Use a repeatable scan cycle to reduce surprises.

docs.title: 2. Signaling Discipline
docs.text: Signal before braking or lateral movement; maintain signal through maneuver; cancel promptly.

docs.title: 3. Space Cushions
docs.text: Keep time-based following gap; adjust lateral position to avoid clustering. Maintain escape route to one side.

docs.title: 4. Courtesy & Predictability
docs.text: Yield voluntarily to defuse aggressive merges; avoid abrupt lane changes; use calm, consistent pacing.

docs.title: 5. Hazard Anticipation
docs.text: Watch for door openings, sudden stops, pedestrians stepping between parked cars, turning vehicles without signals.

docs.title: Quick Self-Check
docs.text:

  • Why maintain an escape route?
  • When to activate turn signal?

Proceed to quiz.

docs.title: 3 things to remember
docs.text:
• Use a repeatable scan cycle (front → mirrors → gauges → sides/blind spots when needed).
  • Keep an escape route; don’t get boxed in.
  • Signal before braking or moving laterally; cancel promptly after.

docs.title: Quick Review
docs.text: What is a good scan pattern? Front, mirrors, instruments, and blind spots when needed.  Why keep an escape route? To avoid being boxed in and to have space for evasive action.  When should you signal? Before braking or lateral movement, and cancel promptly after.

docs.title: Special Driving Conditions (Chapter 9)
docs.text:
TL;DR

Slow down, increase spacing, use appropriate lighting, and make gentle inputs; know skid basics and that bridges freeze first.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: Adaptation strategies for night, rain, fog, snow/ice, and reduced traction events; skid recovery basics. Verify any recommended speed adjustments or chain/tire requirements in official guide.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
• Adjust speed, spacing, and lighting for adverse conditions.
  • Apply traction management in rain, snow, ice.
  • Execute basic skid recovery (steering into direction of travel).
  • Recognize early hazard indicators in reduced visibility.

docs.title: 1. Night Driving
docs.text:
• Increase following distance.
  • Use high beams when appropriate; dim for oncoming traffic.
  • Heighten peripheral scanning for pedestrians or animals.

docs.title: 2. Rain & Hydroplaning Risk
docs.text:
Reduce speed before standing water; loss of grip demands smooth corrections.
  • Slow before standing water.
  • Increase gap; gentle steering & braking.
  • If hydroplaning: ease off accelerator, steer straight until traction returns.

docs.title: 3. Fog
docs.text:
• Use low beams (avoid high beam glare).
  • Reduce speed; maintain larger cushion.
  • Focus on road edge lines for guidance.

docs.title: 4. Snow & Ice
docs.text:
• Gentle inputs: accelerate/brake/steer smoothly.
  • Increase following distance substantially.
  • Bridges freeze first—approach cautiously.

docs.title: 5. Skid Basics
docs.text:
• Rear-wheel skid: Steer in direction you want front to go; avoid brakes until stability returns.
  • Front-wheel skid: Ease off accelerator; steer where you want to go; allow tires to regain grip.

docs.text:

  • Bridge surface hazard in winter?

docs.title: 3 things to remember
docs.text:
• Use low beams in fog; high beams cause glare.
  • If hydroplaning: ease off accelerator and steer straight until traction returns.
  • Snow/ice: gentle inputs and much larger following distances; bridges freeze first.

docs.title: Quick Review
docs.text: Why low beams in fog? High beams reflect and create glare; low beams improve visibility.  What to do if you hydroplane? Ease off the accelerator and steer straight until traction returns.  Winter bridge hazard? Bridges freeze first; slow and be gentle with inputs.

docs.title: Be in Shape to Drive (Chapter 10)
docs.text:
TL;DR

Impairment and fatigue slow reactions and judgment—check meds, plan rest, and minimize distraction overlap.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: Physical, mental, and impairment factors affecting driving: alcohol, drugs (prescription & illicit), fatigue, emotion, distraction interplay. Verify legal BAC limits and any zero-tolerance age specifics in official guide.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
• Recognize impairment types and their effects on reaction time & judgment.
  • Identify fatigue signs and mitigation strategies.
  • Understand medication & driving risk consultations.
  • Apply distraction management techniques.

docs.title: 1. Alcohol & Drug Impairment
docs.text:
• Slows reaction, narrows focus, impairs judgment.
  • Mixing substances compounds effects unpredictably.
  • Designate driver or alternative transport before consuming.

docs.title: 2. Medication Awareness
docs.text:
• Review labels for drowsiness warnings.
  • Consult pharmacist/doctor about combining meds and driving.
  • First-dose caution: Evaluate personal reaction before driving.

docs.title: 3. Fatigue
docs.text:
• Signs: Yawning, drifting, delayed response, microsleeps.
  • Mitigation: Adequate sleep, breaks every ~2 hours, avoid late-night long drives.

docs.title: 4. Emotional State
docs.text:
• Anger or stress can trigger aggressive driving.
  • Strategy: Pause, deep breathing, delay trip if severely agitated.

docs.title: 5. Distraction Interplay
docs.text:
• Cognitive (mind off task), manual (hands off wheel), visual (eyes off road).
  • Use phone only in permitted hands-free manner; avoid complex interaction.

docs.title: Impairment factors
docs.text: Stacked factors compound risk—plan rest and review meds.

docs.title: Quick Self-Check
docs.text:

  • Fatigue warning signs?
  • Difference between visual and cognitive distraction?

Proceed to quiz.

docs.title: 3 things to remember
docs.text:
• Be cautious with first-dose or drowsy medications before driving.
  • Fatigue signs (yawning, drifting, microsleeps) demand breaks or trip delay.
  • Distraction types: visual, manual, cognitive—avoid stacking them.

docs.title: Quick Review
docs.text: Why avoid driving after a first dose of some meds? You don't yet know how they affect alertness or reaction time.  Two fatigue warning signs? Yawning, lane drifting, or microsleeps.  Name the three distraction types. Visual, manual, and cognitive.

docs.text:

Points add up from violations and can trigger suspensions and premium hikes—prevention is safer (and cheaper) than remediation.

• Analyze root cause (speeding, distraction, etc.).

docs.title: Titling & Registration (Chapter 12)
docs.text:
TL;DR

Title proves ownership; registration authorizes road use—keep documents current and renew on time to avoid penalties.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: Core concepts of vehicle titling and registration: purpose, required documentation, renewal considerations. Verify Missouri-specific forms and intervals.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
• Distinguish title vs registration.
  • Know basic documentation needed.
  • Understand renewal responsibility.
  • Recognize consequences of failing to maintain valid documents.

docs.title: 1. Title vs Registration
docs.text: Title proves ownership; registration permits lawful road operation and associates vehicle with plates & fees.

docs.title: Visual: Title vs Registration
docs.text: Different roles: ownership vs permission to operate on roads.

docs.text:
• Proof of ownership (previous title, bill of sale).
  • Identification of owner.
  • Safety/emissions (if applicable, verify state requirements).

  • Fee payment.

docs.title: 3. Renewal & Updates
docs.text: Registrations expire; timely renewal avoids penalties. Update address, ownership changes promptly.

docs.title: 4. Non-Compliance Consequences
docs.text:
• Fines or citations.
  • Potential towing or impound.
  • Delays in future transactions.

docs.title: 5. Best Practices
docs.text:
• Calendar reminders for renewal.
  • Maintain organized document file.
  • Promptly resolve address changes.

docs.title: Distracted Driving (Chapter 16)
docs.text:
TL;DR

Distraction comes in visual, manual, and cognitive forms—reduce device/console interaction and plan routes before driving.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: Nature of distraction (visual, manual, cognitive), common sources, mitigation tactics. Emphasize risk of device interaction and in-vehicle tasks.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
• Identify distraction types.
  • Recognize high-risk behaviors.
  • Apply mitigation strategies.
  • Understand cumulative risk factors (fatigue + distraction).

docs.title: 1. Distraction Categories
docs.text:
• Visual: Eyes off road.
  • Manual: Hands off controls.
  • Cognitive: Mind off driving.

docs.title: 2. Common Sources
docs.text:
Recognize and minimize each category to cut risk.
  • Mobile devices (texting, browsing).
  • Eating/drinking.
  • Adjusting controls (navigation, audio).
  • Passengers or pets.
  • External events (rubbernecking).

docs.title: 3. Risk Amplifiers
docs.text:
• High speed.
  • Adverse weather.
  • Night driving.
  • Fatigue or impairment.

docs.title: 4. Mitigation Strategies
docs.text:
• Pre-set route & audio before departure.
  • Secure loose items.
  • Silence non-essential notifications.
  • Adopt scanning routine to maintain situational awareness.

docs.title: 5. Incident Potential
docs.text: Seconds of inattention can equal football-field travel distance at highway speed; reaction time and hazard detection degrade rapidly.
